125E.title: The Contemporary Novel
125E.description: Important contemporary novels, some of which may be read in translation.

28.title: Introduction to the Study of Drama
28.description: Lectures and discussion intended to develop the student's ability to read, understand and evaluate plays. Designed primarily for students whose major is not English, but majors and prospective majors are welcome.

250.title: Research Seminars
250.description: Required of all Ph.D. students. Advanced study in various fields, leading to a substantial piece of writing. Offerings vary from semester to semester. Students should consult the department's "Announcement of Classes" for offerings well before the beginning of the semester.

246C.title: Graduate Proseminars: Renaissance 16th Century(excluding or at least not prominently ft Shakespeare)
246C.description: Proseminars in the major chronological fields of English and American literature providing graduate instruction in scholarly and critical approaches appropriate to each field.

243N.title: Prose Nonfiction Writing Workshop
243N.description: A writing workshop in prose nonfiction for graduate students.

45C.title: Literature in English: The Mid-19th through the 20th Century
45C.description: Historical survey of literature in English: the mid-19th through the 20th century.

119.title: Literature of the Restoration and Early Eighteenth Century
119.description: Lectures on and discussion of Dryden, Swift, Pope, and some of their contemporaries.

180A.title: Autobiography
180A.description: Lectures on and discussion of autobiographical forms.

299.title: Special Study
299.description: Normally reserved for students directly engaged upon the doctoral dissertation.

203.title: Graduate Readings
203.description: Graduate lecture courses surveying broad areas and periods of literary history, and directing students in wide reading. Offerings vary from semester to semester. Students should consult the department's "Announcement of Classes" for offerings well before the beginning of the semester.

C136.title: Topics in American Studies
C136.description: A course on the intellectual, cultural, historical, and social backgrounds to American literature. Topics will vary from semester to semester. Students should consult the department's "Announcement of Classes" for current offerings well before the start of the semester.

165.title: Special Topics
165.description: Designed primarily for English majors. Topics vary from semester to semester. Students should consult the department's "Announcement of Classes" for offerings well before the beginning of the semester.

143N.title: Prose Nonfiction
143N.description: A seminar in the writing of prose nonfiction as an art.

105.title: Anglo-Saxon England
105.description: Instruction in the basic elements of the Old English language with analysis of literary and cultural issues relating to the formative period of the English nation. (Undergraduates who pass 105 with a grade of B+ or higher, or with permission of the 205B instructor, are eligible to enroll in 205B, Beowulf.)

118.title: Milton
118.description: Lectures on and discussion of Milton's major works.

310.title: Field Studies in Tutoring Writing
310.description: Tutoring Berkeley undergraduates in College Writing R1A, R1A, R1B, and other writing and/or literature courses. Seminar topics: the writing process, responding to writing, composition theory, grammar, collaborative learning, tutoring methods. Tutors keep a weekly journal, read assigned articles, videotape their tutoring, and write a final paper. This course cannot be used toward fulfillment of the major requirements.

143C.title: Long Narrative
143C.description: Students will work through the semester on a single project, either fiction (novel) or nonfiction (biography, history).

99.title: Independent Study
99.description: Meetings to be arranged. Reading and regular conference with the instructor in a field that shall not coincide with that of any regular course and shall be specific enough to enable students to write essays based on their studies.

125C.title: The European Novel
125C.description: Lectures on and discussion of major European novels.

43B.title: Introduction to the Writing of Verse
43B.description: A workshop course intended for students who have recently begun to write verse or who have not previously taken a course in creative writing.

132.title: American Novel
132.description: A survey of major American novels.

H195B.title: Honors Course
H195B.description: This is a two-semester course, graded IP at the end of the first semester. During the second semester, each student will write an honors thesis. Completion of the thesis is required for a passing grade in the course.

166AC.title: Special Topics in American Cultures
166AC.description: Study of a special topic related to the diversity of the United States. Topics vary from semester to semester. Student's should consult the department's "Announcement of Classes" for offerings well before the beginning of the semester.

R1B.title: Reading and Composition
R1B.description: Training in writing expository prose.  Further instruction in expository writing in conjunction with reading literature. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition requirement.

141.title: Modes of Writing (Exposition, Fiction, Verse, Etc.)
141.description: Writing in connection with reading in recent English literature and its continental background.

198BC.title: Berkeley Connect
198BC.description: Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program, offered through various academic departments, that helps students build intellectual community. Over the course of a semester, enrolled students participate in regular small-group discussions facilitated by a graduate student mentor (following a faculty-directed curriculum), meet with their graduate student mentor for one-on-one academic advising, attend lectures and panel discussions featuring department faculty and alumni, and go on field trips to campus resources. Students are not required to be declared majors in order to participate. Course may be repeated for credit.

246J.title: Graduate Proseminars: American 1855 to 1900
246J.description: Proseminars in the major chronological fields of English and American literature providing graduate instruction in scholarly and critical approaches appropriate to each field.

180Z.title: Science Fiction
180Z.description: Study of speculative fiction (or science fiction) as a genre. Topics may vary from semester to semester. Focus may be historical or thematic.

137B.title: Chicana/o Literature and Culture Since 1910
137B.description: Major literary and cultural texts in the Chicana/o tradition from 1910 through the contemporary Chicana/o period.

R1A.title: Reading and Composition
R1A.description: Training in writing expository prose.  Instruction in expository writing in conjunction with reading literature. Satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement.

198.title: Directed Group Study
198.description: Enrollment is restricted by university regulations. Group study in a field that shall not coincide with that of any regular course and shall be specific enough to enable students to write essays based upon their studies.

137T.title: Topics in Chicana/o Literature and Culture
137T.description: Topics in Chicana/o literature and culture.

166.title: Special Topics
166.description: Topics vary from semester to semester. Students should consult the department's "Announcement of Classes" for offerings well before the beginning of the semester.

80K.title: Children's Literature
80K.description: The study of selected works written for children.

24.title: Freshman Seminars
24.description: The Berkeley Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Berkeley Seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester.

246K.title: Graduate Proseminars: Literature in English 1900 to 1945
246K.description: Proseminars in the major chronological fields of English and American literature providing graduate instruction in scholarly and critical approaches appropriate to each field.

84.title: Sophomore Seminar
84.description: Sophomore seminars are small interactive courses offered by faculty members in departments all across the campus. Sophomore seminars offer opportunity for close, regular intellectual contact between faculty members and students in the crucial second year. The topics vary from department to department and semester to semester. Enrollment limited to 15 sophomores.

117S.title: Shakespeare
117S.description: Lectures on Shakespeare and reading of his best works.

130A.title: American Literature: Before 1800
130A.description: Lectures on and discussion of the major writers of the early American period.

190.title: Research Seminar
190.description: Research-oriented and designed for upper-division English majors. Intensive examination of critical approaches, literary theory, or a special topic in literary and cultural studies. Topics vary from semester to semester. Students should consult the department's "Announcement of Classes" for offerings well before the beginning of the semester.

246H.title: Victorian
246H.description: Proseminars in the major chronological fields of English and American literature providing graduate instruction in scholarly and critical approaches appropriate to each field.

180L.title: Lyric Verse
180L.description: Study of lyric forms and techniques.

45A.title: Literature in English: Through Milton
45A.description: Historical survey of literature in English: Beginnings through Milton.

111.title: Chaucer
111.description: Lectures on and discussion of Chaucer's major works.

298.title: Special Studies
298.description: Directed research. Open to qualified graduate students wishing to pursue special topics. If taken to satisfy degree requirements, must be taken for four units and a letter grade.

143A.title: Short Fiction
143A.description: A seminar in writing short stories.

130D.title: American Literature: 1900-1945
130D.description: A survey of modern American literature.

98BC.title: Berkeley Connect
98BC.description:
Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program, offered through various academic departments, that helps students build intellectual community. Over the course of a semester, enrolled students participate in regular small-group discussions facilitated by a graduate student mentor (following a faculty-directed curriculum), meet with their graduate student mentor for one-on-one academic advising, attend lectures and panel discussions featuring department faculty and alumni, and go on field trips to campus resources. Students are not required to be declared majors in order to participate.

Course may be repeated for credit.

43A.title: Introduction to the Writing of Short Fiction
43A.description: A workshop course intended for students who have recently begun to write fiction or who have not previously taken a course in creative writing.

243A.title: Fiction Writing Workshop
243A.description: A writing workshop in fiction for graduate students.

45B.title: Literature in English: The Late-17th through the Mid-19th Century
45B.description: Historical survey of literature in English: The late-17th through the mid-19th century.

139.title: The Cultures of English
139.description: Literatures of various regions in which English is one of the spoken languages, such as Canada, the Caribbean, Australia, Africa, India; and the writings of specific groups or distinctive cultures in the English-speaking world, including the U.S. and the British Isles. Topics vary from semester to semester. Students should consult the department's "Announcement of Classes" for current offerings well before the start of the semester.

199.title: Supervised Independent Study for Advanced Undergraduates
199.description: Meetings to be arranged. Enrollment is restricted by university regulations. Reading and conference with the instructor in a field that shall not coincide with that of any regular course and shall be specific enough to enable students to write essays based upon their studies.
